SystemOutput:
CC:

Fatigue, lightheadedness, and bloating.

HPI:

Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. He reports feeling out of sorts, fatigued, and lightheaded for the past five weeks. He also experiences bloating occasionally. He has been compliant with his medications but admits to struggling with his diet due to recent home renovations. He denies fever, chills, and shortness of breath but reports feeling short of breath when exerting energy during home projects. He experiences slight chest cramps that resolve after about an hour and has a slight cough.

EXAM:

Vitals: Blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygenation within normal limits.
Jugular venous distention: 8 cm
Heart: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur
Lungs: Fine crackles at bases bilaterally
Lower extremities: 1+ pitting edema

RESULTS:

Chest X-ray: Fluid in lungs
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%, mitral regurgitation

IMPRESSION:

1. Congestive heart failure with fluid retention
2. Hypertension, well-managed

PLAN:

1. Congestive heart failure:
   - Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day
   - Patient to weigh himself daily and report weight gain or shortness of breath
   - Order another echocardiogram
2. Hypertension:
   - Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily
   - Patient to continue recording blood pressures at home and report elevated readings via patient portal

Follow up with the patient after test results are received.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female presenting with right knee pain after a fall from a ladder while changing a light bulb yesterday. She reports twisting her knee while trying to catch her fall. The pain is located on the inside of her knee. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it has not provided significant relief.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Atrial fibrillation, currently on digoxin.

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY

Rhinoplasty.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Endorses right knee pain.
• Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Musculoskeletal: Tenderness over the medial portion of the right knee, specifically over the medial meniscus area. Pain with valgus stress. Normal sensation distally.
• Neurological: Intact sensation in the lower extremities.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right knee: No fractures or dislocations. Mild joint effusion.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female presenting with right knee pain after a fall.

Acute medial meniscus strain.
• Medical Reasoning: Based on the mechanism of injury, physical examination, and x-ray findings, the patient likely has an acute medial meniscus strain.
• Medical Treatment: Prescribe a knee brace and crutches for temporary use. Recommend over-the-counter Motrin 800 mg every six hours with food for pain relief.
• Follow-up: Schedule a follow-up appointment in one week. If the pain has not improved, consider ordering an MRI at that time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with lower back pain. The patient reports lifting heavy boxes too quickly and feeling a pop in his lower back approximately 4 days ago. He has experienced stiffness and pain since the incident. He has tried Tylenol, ibuprofen, and icy heat, but these have not provided significant relief. The patient experienced tingling in the toes of his right foot, which resolved on its own.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, or weight loss.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses back pain and stiffness. Denies joint pain elsewhere.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of the lumbar spine. Pain with flexion and extension of the back. Negative straight leg raise.

RESULTS

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

X-ray of the lumbar spine is unremarkable with good bony alignment and no fractures.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

Acute lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports lifting heavy boxes too quickly and feeling a pop in his lower back approximately 4 days ago.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue icing and avoiding strenuous activity.
• Specialist Referrals: Refer to physical therapy for strengthening exercises.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily.
• Additional Testing: Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure readings are slightly elevated.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is managing his knee osteoarthritis well and no further workup is needed at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up in 2 weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam, follow-up on depression, lobectomy, and hypertension.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, prior lobectomy, and hypertension, who presents for his annual exam. The patient reports doing relatively well, with some stress related to moving his daughter into college. He has been managing his depression with Prozac and has not had any recent incidents. He admits to occasionally forgetting to take his hypertension medication on weekends but has been generally compliant. He experiences shortness of breath with exertion during his daily runs, particularly in humid conditions.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Psychiatric: Endorses well-controlled depression.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath with exertion.
• Cardiovascular: Endorses occasional chest pounding during exercise.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Blood Pressure: 120/80
• Heart: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Extremities: No lower extremity edema.
• Sinuses: Pain to palpation.

RESULTS

EKG: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerning findings related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression: Patient is doing well on Prozac 20 mg daily. Continue current treatment and provide a refill.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient reports well-controlled depression with current medication.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily. Refill prescription.

2. Prior lobectomy: No further workup needed. Patient has good exercise tolerance and clear lung sounds on exam.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient's respiratory function appears stable and well-managed.
   • Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with surgeon needed.

3. Hypertension: Blood pressure is well-controlled in the office. Continue current medication (Norvasc).
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure has improved over time and is well-controlled in the office.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Norvasc as prescribed. Encourage patient to maintain medication compliance on weekends.

4. Systolic ejection murmur: Order an echocardiogram to further evaluate.
   • Medical Reasoning: A murmur was detected on physical examination.
   • Medical Treatment: Order an echocardiogram for further evaluation.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment.

CC:

Right index finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Sharon Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right index finger pain after a skiing accident over the weekend. She reports that while skiing, she went over a mogul and her finger got caught and bent backward. The incident occurred on Sunday, and she has been experiencing pain since then. She has tried ice and ibuprofen for pain relief, but it remains painful.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Miralax

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Constipation, appendectomy at age 18

EXAM:

Examination of the right index finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right index finger show no fractures.

IMPRESSION:

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend an aluminum foam splint and a prescription for Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for pain, to be taken for about a week. If the pain does not improve, the patient should call and return for a follow-up. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female who presents with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia. She was recently unable to donate blood due to her anemia. The patient has been experiencing fatigue, shortness of breath, wheezing, headaches, chills, and worsening anxiety and depression. She has been anemic since the age of 13 and had a hysterectomy in 1996. She had a colonoscopy approximately 5-6 years ago with no significant findings.

The patient is currently taking ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily and over-the-counter vitamin B12.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: No murmurs, gallops, or rubs. No extra heart sounds.
• Gastrointestinal: Abdomen is soft and non-tender to palpation. No rebound or guarding. No peritoneal signs.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Iron deficiency anemia.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia with recent worsening symptoms. The cause of her anemia is still unknown.
• Additional Testing: Schedule an upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy.
• Medical Treatment: Continue ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily with orange juice for better absorption. Recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate in 12 weeks.
• Referral: Refer the patient to a hematologist for further evaluation and management.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and incidental discovery of pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Ward is a 52-year-old male who presents with worsening headaches over the past few months. He denies any history of headaches in the past. His past clinical history is unremarkable. Workup for headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where a pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. The patient reports headaches located behind his eyes, described as a dull nagging ache. The onset was gradual, starting about three months ago and worsening over time. The headaches are worse in the morning and last a few hours at a time. The patient denies any other symptoms such as fever, neck stiffness, numbness, weakness, or passing out. However, he reports bumping into door frames recently.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: No fevers, chills.
• Neurological: Positive for headaches, negative for numbness, tingling, or passing out.
• Ophthalmologic: Bitemporal hemianopia noted during examination.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: Alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent.
• Neurological: Cranial nerve examination is grossly intact. No focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities.
• Ophthalmologic: Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

RESULTS

MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21: Pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. Ventricles are normal in size and no other abnormalities are noted.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Mr. Ward is a 52-year-old male with an incidentally discovered pituitary lesion during workup for worsening headaches.

Pituitary adenoma.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has clinical and radiographical evidence of optic chiasmal compression, which is causing his headaches and bitemporal hemianopia.
• Medical Treatment: Surgical intervention to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa is indicated. The patient will be referred to the eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test prior to surgery. The patient will also be scheduled for surgery with a transsphenoidal approach.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill, a 52-year-old female with a past medical history of uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal, presents today as a new patient with a referral from the ER for esophagitis. She experienced chest pain and difficulty swallowing in early October 2020, which resolved after four days. The patient denies any recurrence of symptoms since then. She reports that she was going through a stressful job transition at the time of the symptoms.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fevers, chills, or weight loss.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal pain, normal bowel movements.
• Cardiovascular: Denies shortness of breath, palpitations.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Abdomen: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No rebound tenderness or guarding.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Betty Hill is a 52-year-old female with a past medical history of uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal, who presents today with a referral from the ER for esophagitis.

Possible etiologies:
• GERD
• Dyspepsia
• Esophagitis
• Musculoskeletal etiologies
• Anxiety

Suspect she had an anxiety attack related to her job transition, plus or minus a contribution from her musculoskeletal etiologies.

Plan:
• Discussed the option of EGD versus monitoring for symptoms. The patient elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any reoccurrence or change.
• Follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Evaluation of kidney function in a patient with Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting for evaluation of her kidney function. She is a twin, born at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation, with a birth weight of 4 pounds, 8 ounces. She has a history of feeding difficulties, gastroesophageal reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently receiving feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will soon start speech therapy. She has seen multiple specialists, including a geneticist, who mentioned potential kidney anomalies associated with her syndrome.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: No weight loss. Normal wet diaper count (8-10 per day).
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities.
• Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Eyes: Small appearing.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities and arms.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting for evaluation of her kidney function.

• Medical Reasoning: Congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract have been reported in the literature for patients with Smith-Magenis Syndrome.
• Additional Testing: We will obtain a kidney ultrasound today to screen for any abnormalities.
• Follow-up: If there are abnormalities on the kidney ultrasound, we will determine next steps and future follow-up. The family lives in Dallas, Georgia, so her follow-up should be at the town center location. If the ultrasound is normal, no further follow-up with nephrology will be needed.

Patient Agreements: The patient's family understands and agrees with the recommended medical evaluation plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain and swelling after a fall.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Diana is a patient who presents today with right wrist pain and swelling after a fall while doing laundry. She reports slipping on the stairs and extending her arms to catch herself, resulting in immediate pain and swelling in her right wrist. The injury occurred yesterday morning. She has tried ice, an ace wrap, and ibuprofen for pain relief, but the pain persists. She rates the pain as a 9 out of 10 in severity. She denies any previous injuries to this arm.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Right wrist pain and swelling.
• Neurological: Mild tingling in fingers.

PHYSICAL EXAM

• Musculoskeletal: Obvious swelling and ecchymosis of the right wrist. Tenderness on palpation throughout the wrist. Bony crepitus noted. Pain on flexion, extension, radial deviation, and ulnar deviation. Able to make a fist but not tightly.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist: Positive for a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

• Colles' fracture of the right wrist.

PLAN

1. Apply a brace to the right wrist for immobilization.
2. Schedule surgery for fracture fixation.
3. Prescribe Ultram 50 mg every 6 hours for pain management.
4. Refer to physical therapy for post-surgical rehabilitation.
5. Follow-up appointment in one month to assess progress and discuss vacation plans.

INSTRUCTIONS

1. Wear the brace as instructed.
2. Take pain medication as prescribed.
3. Attend physical therapy sessions as recommended.
4. Follow up in one month to assess progress and discuss vacation plans.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain and hypertension follow-up.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Philip is a patient with a past medical history of hypertension who presents today with right knee pain after a fall on his property a week ago. He reports feeling a pop during the fall and has experienced swelling and pain, particularly during flexion and extension of the knee. The patient has been taking ibuprofen for pain and swelling. He rates his pain as 4 out of 10 when moving the knee. 

Regarding his hypertension, the patient admits to not making significant dietary changes as previously discussed. His blood pressure today was 150/70.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, or weight loss.
• Cardiovascular: No chest pain.
• Respiratory: No shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: No abdominal pain or nausea.
• Musculoskeletal: Right knee pain and swelling.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: Right knee with pain to palpation of the medial aspect, pain with flexion and extension, edema, and effusion.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right knee: No fractures or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain:
   • Medical Treatment: Ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and swelling.
   • Supportive Care: Knee brace, ice application for 20 minutes 3-4 times a day, elevation, and rest.
   
2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Referral to nutritionist for dietary guidance and sodium reduction.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a patient who presents with left shoulder pain for the past three weeks. He is unable to recall any specific injury but has been active and working on renovating his basement. He has had occasional aches and pains in the past but nothing that Tylenol couldn't alleviate. The patient reports difficulty reaching for objects and lifting, as well as increased pain when attempting to sleep on the affected shoulder. He has been taking two extra strength Tylenol every six to eight hours, which provides some relief but does not eliminate the pain.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Left shoulder exam reveals limited active and passive range of motion, tenderness of the greater tuberosity of the humerus, and no tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints. Good hand grips. Neurovascular exam of the left arm shows capillary refill less than three seconds and intact sensation to light touch.

RESULTS

X-ray of the left shoulder shows no fractures.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Rotator cuff tendinopathy.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with rotator cuff tendinopathy, an injury to the tendons of the shoulder muscles.
• Diagnostic Testing: Order an MRI of the left shoulder to rule out any other underlying issues.
• Medical Treatment: Refer the patient to physical therapy for six to eight weeks, during which he may continue taking Tylenol for pain relief. If symptoms do not improve, consider a steroid injection for the shoulder.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

Schedule an MRI for the left shoulder. Begin physical therapy for six to eight weeks. Continue taking Tylenol as needed for pain relief. Schedule a follow-up visit after completing physical therapy. Call the clinic with any questions or new symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain and instability.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Andrea is a patient who presents with occasional left knee pain and instability. She reports that the pain occurs less than once a day and is usually brief. The pain is located internally in the whole kneecap area. She denies any history of injury to the knee or any popping sensation. The patient has not taken any medication for the pain as it does not last long. She is concerned about her knee giving out during an upcoming trip where she will be walking and participating in line dancing.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Positive left knee pain and instability. Denies swelling or injury.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain. Blood pressure controlled with medication.
• Endocrine: Diabetes managed with metformin. Reports fasting blood sugar around 130.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: in no apparent distress.
• Neck: Supple without thyromegaly or lymphadenopathy.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. Appreciates a slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.
• Musculoskeletal: Left knee exam - no ecchymosis, edema, effusion, or pain to palpation. No decreased range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Left knee pain and instability.
   • Medical Reasoning: Likely due to arthritis.
   • Medical Treatment: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily.
   • Additional Treatment: Consider physical therapy to strengthen muscles around the knee.

2. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure controlled with lisinopril.
   • Additional Testing: Order echocardiogram to evaluate heart murmur.

3. Diabetes Mellitus.
   • Medical Reasoning: Fasting blood sugar around 130, managed with metformin.
   • Additional Testing: Order hemoglobin A1c and lipid panel to assess diabetes control and potential adjustments to metformin.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow-up during neo-adjuvant chemotherapy for stage three non-small cell lung cancer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Beverly is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer. She presents for follow-up during neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. She was diagnosed with a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule, and biopsy was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending at this time. The patient reports minimal cough and sore throat today, with some fatigue. She denies nausea or vomiting and shortness of breath.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Respiratory: Endorses minimal cough and sore throat.
• Constitutional: Endorses fatigue.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neck: No cervical or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy.
• Respiratory: Crackles bilaterally in lungs.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
• Skin: Erythema on the anterior left side of the chest, likely related to radiation.
• Extremities: No edema.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Stage three non-small cell lung cancer.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is currently undergoing neo-adjuvant chemotherapy with cisplatin and etoposide.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue current chemotherapy regimen and radiation at 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion to assess tumor shrinkage and potential for surgical removal.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient's cough and bilateral lung crackles are likely due to radiation-induced inflammation.
   • Medical Treatment: Prescribe prednisone 40 mg daily for 5 days to reduce inflammation.

3. Painful swallowing.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient's sore throat may be due to esophageal inflammation from radiation.
   • Medical Treatment: Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow four times a day to alleviate pain and facilitate eating and drinking.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low Immunoglobulin A (IgA) level.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Kyle is a patient who presents today for evaluation of a low Immunoglobulin A (IgA) level, which was discovered during a recent physical examination. The patient reports a history of frequent colds during the winter months, which tend to linger for an extended period. However, the patient does not report any significant abdominal infections or diarrhea. The patient has no known family history of immune deficiencies. The patient was recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and started on metformin.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Type 2 diabetes.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Respiratory: Frequent colds during winter months.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal infections or diarrhea.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vitals: Within normal limits, no fever.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
• Abdominal: Soft, non-tender.

LABORATORY RESULTS

Low Immunoglobulin A (IgA) level.

ASSESSMENT

• Low Immunoglobulin A (IgA) level.
• Type 2 diabetes.

PLAN

Low Immunoglobulin A (IgA) level
• Order additional blood work to check for other antibodies.
• Advise the patient to monitor for infections that do not resolve or are difficult to control, as well as any significant changes in the abdominal tract, such as severe diarrhea.
• Instruct the patient to inform healthcare providers of their IgA deficiency if they require blood products in the future.

Type 2 diabetes
• Continue metformin as prescribed.
• Encourage the patient to maintain a healthy diet and lifestyle.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will complete the additional blood work and return for a follow-up appointment to discuss the results.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Lawrence is a patient who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of right elbow pain. He reports that he has been engaging in pottery and ceramics during the pandemic and has been experiencing pain in his right elbow for the past four days. The pain is located on the inside of his elbow and radiates slightly into his forearm. He denies any trauma or previous injury to the elbow. The pain is rated as a 6/10 and has been affecting his sleep and ability to perform certain activities. He has tried ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Right elbow pain, radiating into the forearm. No shoulder pain.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vitals: Stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Positive for pain to palpation at the medial epicondyle of the right elbow. Pain with pronation of the forearm. Pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right elbow: No fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

• Medial epicondylitis of the right elbow.

PLAN

1. Rest: Instructed the patient to rest the affected elbow and provided a sling to wear while awake.
2. Ice: Advised the patient to apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes, three times a day.
3. Medication: Prescribed ibuprofen 600 mg q.6 h. with food for one week.
4. Activity modification: Instructed the patient to avoid pottery work for the next couple of weeks.
5. Follow-up: Scheduled a follow-up appointment in one week to evaluate progress.

Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the diagnosis and treatment plan with the patient, who understands and agrees with the recommendations.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and shortness of breath.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

David is a middle-aged male with a history of hypertension who presents with chest pain and shortness of breath. He reports falling down while walking outside and experiencing chest pain, which he initially dismissed as heartburn. He also reports some shortness of breath but did not think much of it. The patient admits to not consistently taking his hypertension medications and not following a strict diet, consuming salty foods such as chips.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Endorses chest pain and shortness of breath.
• Respiratory: Denies difficulty sleeping.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Blood pressure: 128/72
• Neck: No jugular venous distention.
• Cardiovascular: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Extremities: Trace edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram: Preserved ejection fraction of 55%, normal diastolic filling, and mild to moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

David is a middle-aged male with a history of hypertension presenting with chest pain and shortness of breath.

Congestive heart failure (CHF).
• Medical Reasoning: Based on the patient's dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension, the CHF is likely caused by these factors.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Bumex 2 mg once daily. Consult with nutrition for dietary advice.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Advise the patient to weigh himself daily and call if he gains 3 pounds in 2 days. Encourage adherence to medications and a low-salt diet.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has a history of uncontrolled hypertension and has not been consistently taking his medications.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Order a renal artery ultrasound for further evaluation.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Encourage the patient to take medications consistently and monitor blood pressure at home.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a patient who presents with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain moves to his lower abdomen and into his groin. The pain is intermittent and severe when it occurs. The patient reports difficulty finding a comfortable position during the pain episodes. He experiences burning sensation during urination and notes that his urine appears darker than usual. He has taken Tylenol for the pain, but it has not provided significant relief. The patient feels nauseated but has not vomited.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Kidney stones.

FAMILY HISTORY

Father had kidney stones.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs.
CVA: Positive tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS
Imaging

CT scan of the abdomen: 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. No evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).

PLAN

1. Encourage increased fluid intake to facilitate urination and stone passage.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6-8 hours as needed for pain. Continue alternating with Tylenol.
3. Provide a urine strainer to collect the stone for analysis.
4. Order basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and urine culture.
5. Schedule follow-up appointment in 1-2 weeks to assess progress and discuss further treatment options (e.g., lithotripsy or ureteroscopy) if necessary.
6. Instruct the patient to contact the clinic if symptoms worsen.

INSTRUCTIONS

Follow the prescribed treatment plan and contact the clinic if symptoms worsen. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1-2 weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT:

Nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer on the right foot.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy who presents with a nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer on his right foot. He first noticed the ulcer about six weeks ago after wearing tight shoes. The ulcer initially presented as a blister but has since become unroofed with thick, soft, and mushy skin. The patient reports a foul smell and yellow drainage from the wound. He has been on antibiotics for six days and has experienced a fever of 99.7°F and chills. The patient also reports that the wound has turned black around the edges, and he has been experiencing cramping in his calf muscle and a red streak along the inside of his calf muscle. He has also been coughing and having difficulty catching his breath.

The patient's blood sugars have been trending in the 300-400 range for the past two weeks, with one spike at 500-600. His A1C is 6.7, and he has been well-controlled for the past two years.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:

Vital Signs: Slight fever, otherwise stable.
Foot Exam: Necrotic wound on the heel, approximately 2x2 cm, with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythemia. No bony exposure. No pain on palpation of the affected area.
Vascular Exam: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses. Non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.

RESULTS:

Right foot X-ray: No evidence of osteomyelitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer: Order a test to check blood supply for the wound. Perform debridement in the office today. Obtain a culture and consider different antibiotic therapy based on the results. Monitor the redness and swelling in the patient's leg. Follow up in seven days.

2. Diabetes management: Encourage the patient to follow up with his endocrinologist to maintain his A1C below 7 and closely monitor his blood sugars during the course of antibiotic and other medication therapy.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite and possible Lyme disease.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Richard is a patient with a history of hypertension and diabetes who presents today with a tick bite on his right knee. The patient is unsure where he acquired the tick bite but has been spending time outdoors, including hunting. The tick bite has been present for over a week and is causing burning and discomfort. The patient denies fever or chills but has experienced a headache and general malaise since the tick bite. He denies any other joint pain, difficulty moving his knee, or problems walking. The patient has had tick bites in the past but has never been diagnosed with Lyme disease.

Regarding his hypertension, the patient has been taking lisinopril and checking his blood pressure periodically, which has been well-controlled. He denies any side effects from the medication.

For his diabetes, the patient has been taking metformin and monitoring his blood sugar levels, which have been running in the 120s. He admits to not taking metformin every day but most of the time.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, or weight loss. Endorses headache and general malaise.
• Musculoskeletal: Denies joint pain other than arthritic pain.
• Neurological: Denies dizziness.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Blood pressure 122/70, heart rate 67, temperature 98.4.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmur, rub, or gallop.
• Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Musculoskeletal: Erythema, edema, and area of fluctuance over the right patella with pain to palpation. Full range of motion of the right knee.
• Skin: Bull's-eye rash over the right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Tick bite and possible Lyme disease.
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient presents with a tick bite on his right knee accompanied by a bull's-eye rash, which raises concern for Lyme disease.
   • Additional Testing: Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm the diagnosis.
   • Medical Treatment: Initiate doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for three weeks.

2. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure is well-controlled on lisinopril.
   • Additional Testing: Order a lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg once daily.

3. Diabetes.
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood sugar levels have been well-controlled on metformin.
   • Additional Testing: Order a hemoglobin A1c and basic metabolic panel to assess long-term blood sugar control and kidney function.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue metformin 1000 mg twice daily.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.
